When we go in as a chaplain, we go in to be a listening ear.
We certainly don't want to go in to condemn anyone.
We want to go in to lift up their spirits and to provide a service to them.
If there's a death in the family, we will conduct a funeral no charge to the employees whatsoever.
If there's a need for a wedding, and they don't have church, we will conduct a wedding.
Someone in the family sick - we'll make hospital visits, and just provide support and encouragement and hope for many people who, as life throws them a curve, feel there is no hope.
I'm wondering if there's ever been a moment when you were rebuffed by someone in the company because you come form a Christian background?
I believe that all of the chaplains at Marketplace Chaplains come from a Christian background, and not everyone in this country is a Christian, I meanâ€¦
That's correct.
You know, do you ever feel that people can't relate to you?
Well, you know, it's interesting.
We go in with a smile.
We do not force ourselves upon anyone.
We move around in the workplace.
We respect each individual's right to utilize our services or not.
But my experience is that sometimes it's those individuals who might initially did not see a need for the chaplain that we're still able to serve.
Let me just give you a quick example.
We had an individual who had told his supervisor that he was going to commit suicide.
And he told me up front, he said I am an atheist and I do not believe in anything about God.
And my comment was I'm not here to talk religion.
If you would like to talk, I'll be happy to talk with you.
I'm here to encourage you, to give you hope.
And we sat there for about three hours.
And that evening I got a call from the girlfriend, and she saw him lying on the floor.
I told her to hang up and call 911 and that I would be there.
When I arrived, this individual was sitting up in the chair with the paramedics and the police and they were trying to convince him to let them take him to a local hospital.
But he said no.
The fact that I've been there with him earlier that day for about three hours, I just walked up to him and said, John, let's get some help.
Put my arms around him, and his comment was I will go if you will take me.
It seems that you get a great satisfaction out of the work you do, and certainly a story like that indicates that you're helping people.
Do you ever feel, though, that what you're doing is incomplete because, from what I understand, at Marketplace Chaplains you can't evangelize?
Do you ever feel, well, I wish I could talk to him more about religion?
I wish I could take that step and do what I went to divinity school to do.
Or is this your mission now?
Well, my mission is to help people regardless of who they are, regardless of what they've ever done.
And many times, people are hurting and they're looking for hope.
And many times, we may be that last hope - just showing love and caring for.
Well, Mr. Gray, thank you very much for sharing your time.
